dlgPart.npc_text:
Paullus’ men approach the Aurelians in close formation and their new allies greet them with cheers, as what seemed a hopeless slog suddenly has the look of a triumph. You alone, knowing what is to come, recognize the tension in the approaching soldiers. Nowhere do you see a smile or a friendly wave, or an iota of slackened discipline.
In grim silence, Paullus’ highest officer and bodyguards step into the Aurelian command tent, and moments later the charade ends in blood.
With no more emotion than a butcher rendering a calf, the interlopers fall on their victims without mercy. By the time the defenders manage to assemble a formation, half of their men have been incapacitated or slain. In the instant when it appears that the Aurelians may in spite of everything rally, the sound of a distant gong signals the opening of Ganezzar’s main gates. Crassus’ troops push forward in a wave, driving the remaining Aurelian forces ahead of them into the hills.
The siege is broken.

Carrinas’ legionaries keep up the charade until the very last moment. The Aurelian soldiers, believing them to be the vanguard of the army, respond with cheers, but their enthusiasm turns to ragged shouts of warning as the Imperial Guards level their weapons and charge. Like a spear through a paper screen, the Imperial Guards burst through the defenders’ ranks to overrun the command tent.
In that same moment, the sound of a distant gong signals the opening of Ganezzar’s main gates and Crassus’ troops spill out, adding to chaos and confusion. By the time the Aurelians manage to assemble a defensive line, half of their men have been incapacitated or slain and soon the remainder are broken. Although few of Carrinas’ legionaries are still standing and the bodies of Meru’s zealots litter the ground, their sacrifice hasn’t been in vain. The Aurelian forces are devastated, and with no prospect of reinforcements they are compelled to withdraw.
Crassus’ legatus, oblivious to the blood covering the left side of his face and running down his neck, does not look to you but simply nods once, satisfied.
The siege is broken.

In the hour before dawn, the Sellsword Legion rises from the hills like shadows silently come to life. The Aurelian watchmen must at some point have grown lazy, for no alarm sounds as the mercenaries raise their voices in a single terrifying shriek and rush the besiegers’ camp from all sides. Chaos ensues, with bitter curses, the clashing of blades, and ripping of canvas punctuated by the deep thump of bombs detonating, killing men from both sides. The mercenaries are wild-eyed from ingesting mushrooms, or simply bloodlust, and counter the discipline of their foes with a reckless disregard for their own lives.
When it becomes clear that the sellswords are killing at least as many as they are losing, Ganezzar’s main gates yawn wide, Crassus’ troops pour out, and confusion becomes havoc. By the time the Aurelians manage to assemble a defensive line, half of their men have been incapacitated or slain and soon the remainder are broken. The corpses of the sellswords and Meru’s zealots lay thick on the ground, but their sacrifice hasn’t been in vain. Though they dealt as much death as anyone could expect, the Aurelian forces are devastated, and with no prospect of reinforcements they are compelled to withdraw.
As you regard this grim shambles, one of the mercenaries is still whooping and leaping about, thrusting his spear at invisible enemies, until at the end of one particularly wild stagger he falls full on the blade of a sword, wedged point upward between two corpses.
The siege is broken.

The Aurelians welcome Paullus’ legion with a wild cheer, but rather than fall to drinking and talk, the men begin at once setting up tents and unloading supplies from Paullus’ train. Meru and his cadre observe stone-faced from the barbican above the gate. If anyone is thinking that perhaps Meru should apply to his gods for help, he wisely keeps this counsel to himself.
Paullus sends a messenger to invite Meru to discuss terms, and it appears you are in for a long siege.

The Aurelians welcome Antidas’ forces with cautious optimism, waiting until you present your credentials to their Legatus. Meru and his cadre observe stone-faced from the barbican above the gate. If anyone is thinking that perhaps Meru should apply to his gods for help, he wisely keeps this counsel to himself.
Relieved, the Legatus declines to examine this gift horse’s mouth and offers Antidas’ men, renowned for their bravery, the honor of leading the attack.

dlgAnsw.text: You graciously accept and prepare to lead the attack yourself.

You graciously accept and like a true leader order your men to prepare to die, while you’ll observe the carnage from the command tent, enjoying the Legatus’ wine – not the finest vintage but that’s war for you.

The bodies of Meru, his magus, and the prophet are being loaded like firewood into the back of a cart. Meru’s throat has been cut in a single clean stroke, but the magus’ corpse has been slashed and hacked like a legionnaire’s practice dummy. His eyes and fingers are missing.
“The bodies will be displayed above the gates of Ganezzar and given proper rites afterwards,” explains the Legatus. “Meru and the prophet didn’t give us any trouble, but the fucking magus worked his spells on my own men, turning three of them against us. We had to kill them – good men too.”
“Taken for trophies. Eyes and fingers make good talismans, or so I am told.”

You are just in time for one of Meru’s speeches. He seems different somehow. His presence dominates the throne hall, his eyes shine with conviction, transfixing the audience.
“The Gods are with us,” states Meru with immovable certainty. “They have not and will never abandon the faithful. Today they delivered us from great peril. The forces of darkness had gathered outside our walls, ready to tear our city down brick by brick, life by life.
“They would have killed women and children without pity for the crime of having faith in something greater than petty squabbles, for the sin of having hope. But the Gods, the Gods would have none of that and their will cannot – ever – be denied.”

“But I didn’t see any Gods on the battlefield, some of you might say. You didn’t have to. The Gods’ ways are different than those of men. The gods have no need to wield swords, for they only need to move the hearts of righteous men.
“A great transformation took place today. The Imperials Guards have been awakened by the divine and given purpose. The guards of the fallen Empire of Men have become the guards of the new Kingdom of Gods, protectors of our faith.
“Never again you will know fear in your own city, your own homes, for the Gods are finally with us!”
A few people drop to their knees and everyone in the hall follows them, bowing their heads and murmuring prayers.

“My Lord,” says Paullus in a conversational tone as he enters the hall, followed by his personal guards.
“Brother Paullus,” smiles Meru, extending his hand for a kiss.
“I want to talk to you about Al-Akia,” says Paullus, ignoring the hand. “You and I, we made a deal. As long as you stick with your end of it, I’ll stick with mine. Fucking around with things that should be left alone constitutes a breach of that deal. You can talk about gods all you want, but try to bring one and you will regret that you dragged me into all this. Are we clear?”

“Of course,” says Meru, managing to smile. “Very clear.”
“Then you’ll be glad to hear that the gods guided my hand and delivered you from temptation,” says Paullus. “My men blew up that pyramid in Al-Akia a few hours ago. It will rain bricks for a week.”
“You did what?” whispers Meru, suddenly pale.
“Chalk it up to divine will, old boy. Now, Legatus <charname> will stay here and keep an eye on you. Needless to say, I expect you to be on your best behavior.”

“Dux,” salutes the Aurelian Legatus. “Now that Ganezzar is taken –”
“Now that Ganezzar is taken,” says Paullus, interrupting him, “maintaining order is the highest priority. I’m certain you’d agree with this sentiment.”
“It was my understanding that Lord Gaelius’ troops would be taking over,” the Legatus says firmly.
“And it was my understanding that our soon-to-be-Emperor wouldn’t have any troops, but that’s the thing about understandings. They are subject to interpretations. So until I see Gaelius delivering on his promises, Ganezzar remains under our control. Your troops will remain here as well, but you’re free to leave at any time, Legatus.”

“Praetor,” says the Legatus. “I trust you’d inform Lord Gaelius that Ganezzar is taken and the Imperial Guards were killed during the siege.”

“You did well, <charname>. I’m going to leave you in charge. You will govern Ganezzar in my absence and ensure that the city returns to normalcy as soon as possible.
“Gaelius’ troops should be integrated into your own. I’m sure they will resist at first, crucify every tenth and they will fall in line before you know it. I’m going to make you a Legatus, not because you deserve it or because you’re ready, but because I trust you and your position demands it. When Gaelius’ Legatus returns, I want him talking to an equal.”
“You did well, <charname>. I’m sure that Strabos will be pleased. Maseus will be the new magistratus of the city, so talk to him if you need anything.”
“The satisfaction of a job well done, I suppose,” says Paullus.
“Tell Gaelius we have a deal,” says Paullus.
“You fought well, Praetor,” says Paullus. You have a feeling that it’s the highest praise he can give you. “Tell Gaelius we have a deal.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Yes. As long as he gets something in return.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “We don’t make deals with this scum,” says Paullus. “A cross is all he’s going to get when we take the city.”

This is the moment when two contingents of Ordu archers appear on the hills, while a third group similarly arises like ghosts from the forest floor to attack the Guards from the rear, forcing them to fall back to the only logical position, higher ground and the castle gate. However, a group of previously unseen Aurelian reserves, like the third consecutive roll of double skulls in a game of dice, appears to block the gate, locking their shields against the Guards’ last hope.

The Aurelians expend little effort in this fight, grimly and quietly maintaining the line as a black cloud of arrow shafts, implacable as a storm front, sweeps over the Imperial Guards, leaving the remaining soldiers, dragged back from the cusp of victory, to be ground beneath the boots of the Ordu. A few of the Guard’s hardest, those whose discipline does not waiver in their cups, nor asleep, nor even in bed with a woman, form a phalanx and push back against the Ordu, but one of their master archers, having saved his last arrow for just this purpose, tracks Paullus in the formation, and puts it through his eye. The leader’s fall is truly the end. The jaws of the trap close. There are no survivors.
"Didn’t work out?" asks Paullus.
"Then we do it the hard way."
